dialogues.text: It is the first time we have seen it. There are about girls very busy. Morning confusion. (parts to be We pick up essential lines as we PAN DOWN SHOOTING AT GIRL'S FACES, assuming the CAMERA to be the board.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL ONE
dialogues.text: Grand Hotel -- good morning -- no, Baron von Gaigern's room does not answer... Yes,... all right... Baron von Gaigern's chauffeur calling.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL THREE
dialogues.text: Good morning, nine-thirty Doctor Otternschlag... No, Doctor, no messages... No, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL FIVE
dialogues.text: Grand Hotel -- good morning... who is calling Madam Grusinskaya?... Oh, Mr. Pimenov. Madam Grusinskaya is not to be disturbed, sir... no, sir... yes, sir -- The word passes down repeated.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Preysing's calls to one sixty two for today.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL EIGHT
dialogues.text: -- good morning... Mr. Preysing -- (she plugs through)

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Telephone bell ringing. General shot. Gerstenkorn, an old business man and Doctor Waitz, counsel for the Saxonia organization are sitting at a gree table, smoking and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (glances at watch) Nine-thirty, Mr. Preysing keeps us waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has returned) He likes to play the great man.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: (glancing at market report from table) The Preysing stock is holding its own today on the market.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: Ask Preysing what it's costing him to keep it up.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: And ask me what it's costing us to hammer it down.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: If the Preysing people get the Manchester contract, we shall certainly merge with the Preysing company -- but if they haven't they're ruined -- Preysing will have to declare himself.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: Shhh -- here he is now. The door opens and Flaemmchen enters. She is agreeably surprised to see the room full of men. She likes men.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (beams) Good morning, gentlemen -- Mr. Preysing will be here in a minute. Business of Schweimann and Flaemmchen. Gerstenkorn, making notes, glances at his watch again. Door opens suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (enters) Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late, I've been waiting for Justice Zinnowitz, my legal advisor.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: Oh -- ho -- you want legal aid against us? -- The whole thing seems to me to be very simple.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Very simple -- I've always liked the way you dressed, Preysing -- English, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (disturbed) What?

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (quickly) They turn out marvelous material in Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Manchester -- yes. Yes, yes, they do. Yes -- Now gentlemen shall we begin at the beginning? -- Have we cigars -- water and everything? Flaemmchen, who has been busy preparing her little table for work is seen in several CLOSEUPS:

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: (with a wink to Gerstenkorn) Manchester is a very interesting city, don't you think so, Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (stalling) Manchester -- yes -- yes. A man in the textile industry naturally has to know Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: There's a lot of business to be done with the Manchester Cotton Company. They've the whole English market  right in their hands. Have you any connections with -- Manchester?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (quickly) We have a good many connections in England, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: I mean with the Manchester people?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (looking at Gerstenkorn impudently) We are here to discuss our merger. Naturally I can make no statement at this time. We must begin at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (winking at Schweimann) All right.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (far-away commencing to read his report) Since, on the eleventh of June, this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger between our respective firms was entered into -- both parties have fully agreed that this merger can result only in mutual advantages. INTERCUT this speech, which if played by Beery will be interesting, with signals, winks and signs between the other three men.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'm laying before you the last general statement of our concern. Active capital, plant and machinery, raw material and finished product -- for instance -- mop rags --

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Mop rags --!  on rushes is

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: Business between Preysing and Flaemmchen finding papers "Mop Rag! report.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: What we want to know about is Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Preysing -- that's what we want to know.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'd like to wait for Justice Zinnowitz, before I commit myself.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Oh -- Preysing, Preysing --

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: No water -- What a place!

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: All you have to do is phone for it. Flaemmchen, who is on her toes and busy every minute, to the telephone and gives an order -- her conversation heard over the conversation of the men in the room --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Water -- seltzer, three or four bottles and cigars -- good ones.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: I can see this session is going to be exhaustive.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Now to proceed with the projected merger, the advantages for the Saxonia are so obvious...

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Oh -- now let's talk like adults. You want to tell us now a along story of what your factory can do. We know all that you could tell us and if you tell the truth it wouldn't sound  Zinnowitz so good. When you first approached us...

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: We did not approach you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: (quickly looking through the papers) Letter on file September fourteenth would show that you approached...

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (snatching the document from his hand -- losing his temper) It isn't so -- this was a response to a tentative feeler of your own.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (snatching the document violently away) Tentative my foot -- a month before this your old father-in-law came very privately and scratched at my door.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Scratched -- (he nearly chokes) We did not take the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Of course you took the initiative. enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen -- I see the conference is already underway.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Oh, here you are, Justice Zinnowitz -- I'm at cross-purposes with these gentlemen -- will you clear up the situation?

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: But the situation is perfectly clear If you will allow me -- (he clears his throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How clear is Manchester?

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Foggy -- frightfully foggy, always, I'm told. (to Preysing) Have you said anything about Manchester, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I can make no statement about Manchester at this time.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Well -- gentlemen. There is dead silence for a moment -- he clears his throat, commences in almost the same tone as Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Since, on the eleventh of June of this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger...

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (over Zinnowitz's voice -- with a sigh -- sits back) Thank God we're beginning at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: (stops suddenly -- takes glasses from his nose -- he is speaking, not reading) As you remember it -- when you approached us...

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (bangs the paper down) We did not approach you.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I know you did -- I said you did --

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: And I said we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: attention perfume continues

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: is drawn And I know we didn't. During all this commotion Flaemmchen is paying no whatsoever. She is calmly spraying herself with a atomizer and smiling at a gentleman. The noise over her.

dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The atmosphere has changed, the sun shines. Grusinskaya reclining on the chaise-lounge -- her Chinese robe about her. She speaks voluably.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on  the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: And what do you do -- now?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (seriously) I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief. (he turns away)

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: That's a silly joke.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (turns -- takes both her hands) Please look at me. You must believe me -- you must believe that I love you -- that I have never known what love is -- until last night.  (he releases her hands and turns away again.)

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: What is the matter? He does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Flix! The Baron takes the pearls out of his pocket and lays them before her.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (with a little cry of pain) Oh -- (in the silence Grusinskaya puts her head in her hands and thinks) The Baron makes a gesture as if to stroke her hair and then holds back.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (softly) Did you come here just -- just for that? Oh -- it's horrible. Pause. She is suddenly cold.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (passionately) I don't want them now.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (broken) I'll not denounce you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: So --

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I wanted money desperately -- Can you understand? -- That's why I wanted the pearls. I was threatened -- I was desperately in need of a certain big sum of money. I've been following you -- I've admired you. But I have forced myself not to think about you -- Last night, at last, I managed to came into your room and -- and now.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (softly) And now?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I couldn't go through with it. (his head goes down into her lap -- he sighs:) Remarkable. His hand touches her hair -- tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Yes -- yes -- yes. There is a sudden knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Quickly -- here. With a quick gesture Grusinskaya beckons the Baron to the  bathroom. He disappears into the bathroom. She opens the door, after finding the key and radiantly addresses Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: (delighted to see her in a good mood) Good morning, Madam. She puts the coffee down on the table. Charming piece of business as Suzette, in putting the coffee down on the table must necessarily push back the heavily crested cigarette case of the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam has slept well?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Oh, yes, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam will dress now, it is late.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Five minutes, Suzette, come back in five minutes. I'll ring.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, madam Suzette knows all about it. She is a French woman. She is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam is beautiful this morning. As Grusinskaya hurries Suzette to the door she says:

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Yes, Suzette. Suzette goes out. Quickly Grusinskaya crosses and flings open the bathroom door. The Baron comes out.  telephone a to telephone. covers frowns other.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: You must go now. As she speaks the telephone goes. She gives the dirty look. Telephone rings again. She pulls him across the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: There -- it begins. With a hand in his she lifts the telephone receiver and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Hello -- hello -- Meierheim? Yes... During this scene the Baron is touching her shoulder. A charming light moment. She continues to speak into His touch probably tickles her, she laughs -- quickly the receiver so that Meierheim will not hear her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (to Baron) No -- During this scene she is listening to Meierheim. She suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: What?... Cancel Vienna?... Are you mad? We always have great success in Vienna... Certainly not. Come here and see me... yes... good-bye. She turns to the Baron and their arms go around each The telephone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (quickly) There -- the day begins... I must go to rehearsal. She lets the telephone ring.  Telephone

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya --

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: You do believe that I really love you?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd die after last night.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I want to be good to you -- madly good.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Suzette will be back here in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'll go -- good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Shall I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: I--
dialogues.text: bell rings again.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Suzette will be back here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: When are you leaving Berlin?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Very early in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: For Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you come too -- I think it would be better -- for us -- for us both.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Oh -- yes but -- later.  They move Telephone She holds

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Why later?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I have no money now -- I must get some first -- I must get some.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: I'll give you what you need -- I have money.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Oh no -- that would spoil everything. I'll -- I will manage somehow -- I'll manage myself. I will go with you. When does the train leave?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a whole day. I'll be on that train. towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: I shall dance and you'll be with me and then -- listen -- After that you will come with me to Lake Como, I have a villa there. The sun will be shining. I will take a vacation -- six weeks -- eight weeks. We'll be happy and lazy. And then you will go with me to South America -- oh! starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: You must go now. Be careful on your way to your room.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'll go. -- I love you. (he kisses her) I'll be on that train. I'll get the money. him back. The telephone is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Don't do anything foolish -- I'm alarmed about you.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll be on the train. (he kisses her) He leaves. Alone with the telephone bell ringing, Grusinskaya breathes deeply, stretches herself. She goes to the glass and looks at herself -- smiling. Happily she takes the pearls, kisses them, drops them into the casket -- picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (speaking into telephone) Yes, Pimenov... Yes... where are you, in your room? Come, I will see you now... hurry. She rises from the telephone flutteringly, she is humming a tune. She crosses to the mirror, pulls back her hair happily, she is indeed younger. Suzette is putting out a dark dress.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Not that dark dress -- something light -- bright -- it's a sunny morning, Suzette. Suzette happily glances at her. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Come in. (sings) Pimenov enters, before he can speak --

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Pimenov.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: (a little puzzled at  change in her) Good morning, Gru -- your -- Before he can start speaking of last night she quickly speaks:

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Pimenov, I have an idea -- a new ballet -- it must have mad music -- I'll explain it to you later. But now, hurry to the theatre -- I want full rehearsal -- properties -- full ballet and some musicians. Hurry -- Quickly. I will be there -- During this scene Grusinskaya has not looked at him, she is busy in the glass. Nice photography on hair and face. Side scene between Suzette and Pimenov, as Suzette shows him the cigarette case on the table. As he goes through the door Grusinskaya crosses and almost sweeps Suzette to the door with him.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: Gru -- you are positively radiant.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Yes, Pimenov. (quickly to Suzette) One minute, Suzette, I will call you. They leave. Grusinskaya shuts the door. She sweeps happily to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (very very softly - her voice is like music to operator) Hello -- will you -- will you get me Baron von Gaigern, please... yes... Baron von Gaigern -- yes... While she waits, she moves with a sense of dance.

dialogues.text: same

dialogues.text: key desk. is busy, (again into telephone) Will you get me Baron von Gaigern, please... (she speaks quietly) Cherie... yes... it is you... nothing... good morning, good morning, cherie... nothing... no... just to tell you I'm happy.

dialogues.text: I've told you three times -- Baron  a Doctor. following shop the Baron shop of shot. von Gaigern is out.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Did he leave any message for me?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: No, he did not -- there is no message. This whole scene is played in a very low key, almost in whisper, it is interrupted by the entrance of the

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Any letters?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: No, doctor. During this short scene the chauffeur saunters off. Kringelein comes to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, Doctor, such a day -- such a day! They move away from the scene. Kringelein's voice diminishes as the CAMERA MOVES the chauffeur. dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Madam Grusinskaya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the flowers and handing them to clerk) For Madam Grusinskaya.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (to page boy) Madam Grusinskaya -- at once --

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: (to Baron) Your chauffeur's been waiting, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (Quickly -- shortly) All right. (he glances around apprehensively) Kringelein is speaking to the doctor. The Baron approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Baron, we must have gone a hundred miles an hour, at least...

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Yes, quite.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (to doctor) We've been together all day... and in an aeroplane.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Life is changing you, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks to the Baron. The best shops, the very best. Look, Doctor, silk -- feels so nice on the skin... a London hat, see -- made in England, that's silk, too -- fifty marks... Look, the price is on it. That was half my salary before. The Baron is a very fine gentleman -- no one in my life has been so nice to me as the Baron.  coat. CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'm going to change and we'll meet for a drink in the Yellow Room.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: In the Yellow Room, where the music's playing and the ladies are?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (amused) Where the music's playing and the ladies are... The Baron leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No pain, Mr. Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Pain? Oh, no, Doctor. I think if I had pain I'd be too happy to notice it... NOTE: Find cut here. While Kringelein is talking, they move away from the

dialogues.text: We must have the feeling that these men have been all day. Cognac bottles, cigar ends, selzer water, of some sandwiches. In other words it is a business battlefield. Preysing is drawn and tired. Zinnowitz is his feet. Flaemmchen is fast asleep in her chair, pretty picture.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: ..and let me say again for the tenth time... (he is hoarse and tired) ..you people were quite ready for the merger. You declared yourselves... fully agreed on all the terms -- Why should the signing of these articles be suddenly held up?

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: I've admitted that at one time we had reason for desiring ther merger -- What reason have we now? The Preysing Company has fallon upon evil days, very evil days. Preysing jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Evil days -- I've shown you here -- (he bangs the paper) -- my company exports to the Balkans alone, sixty-five thousand marks worth of mop rags a year.  wilted. telegram this

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Mop rags -- mop rags -- we're interested in something quite different!

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: (to Gerstenkorn -- with a sigh) Shall I tell them again?

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (glancing at his watch) Why waste time -- it's getting late.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: You see -- what we are interested in --

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Ah, come on -- we're going home. Due to the long tedious session the men's collars are

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: (rising) Mr. Preysing has too scrupulous a regard for certainties...

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: You've talked enough today, you're hoarse now.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: His hand goes to his pocket. Slowly he takes out the and glances at it. The following scene is played over closeup.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Preysing. (he gets his hat)

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (nervously) You've decided against the merger?

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Then, it's all over?

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: (to Zinnowitz) Well -- well -- You could call my office. There is a general movement to go.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF TELEGRAM
dialogues.text: Trembling in Preysing's hand. "DEAL WITH MANCHESTER

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerstenkorn crosses to Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull through. This is a very bad time to be in such a crisis. We've...

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Why talk -- it's over -- it's over -- it's finished. You've broken off negotiations. You did it. You're calling them off. You had nothing on your mind all day, but Manchester, -- Manchester -- Manchester. (he develops almost a passion) You don't suppose for one moment that I'm such a fool as not to have something that I could say definitely about Manchester. (he is generating almost a passion)

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Oh no -- no -- the session is over. Let's go, it's off. Thank you, gentlemen. (he starts packing up his papers.)

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: If you actually have news from Manchester then...

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am now free to announce... (he is perspiring, his hands are trembling) ..that the deal between my firm and the Manchester Cotton Company has been successfully negotiated.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Preysing, you're joking with us.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: You're a deep one.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: In that case give us the articles. We'll sign at once. We know all the details...

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (smiling, slowly folds up the telegram and puts it back in his pocket) I thought we'd suspended negotiations, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Under these circumstances it's quite a different matter.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Under these circumstances we might refuse to sign.  By this time, Waitz and Zinnowitz have the articles out upon the table. Preysing is perspiring. Gerstenkorn puts his arms around Preysing's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Come on -- business is business -- Come on -- Preysing stands, looking ahead of him. Gerstenkorn picks up the papers glances at them, looks at Waitz. Flaemmchen is awakening.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: Here's my signature -- here Preysing, sign here.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: What a session this has been. While Preysing is signing.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
dialogues.text: It's twenty-five to six.

dialogues.speaker: WAITZ
dialogues.text: We should celebrate this with a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: GERSTENKORN
dialogues.text: (with his hat and coat) See you soon, Preysing. Next week we'll meet and discuss further details.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Next week. Hasty hand-shaking, business of exits. Waitz, Gerstenkorn and Schweimann out. Preysing has not moved.  to dry violence. papers, motions Preysing trying Zinnowitz takes the agreement and waves it in the air the signature.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (to himself) Next week.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: You let me talk till I'm hoarse and you had Manchester sewed-up all the time. Why? Preysing does not answer. Zinnowitz amiably shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Well -- the deal has been put through. Preysing commences to laugh suddenly with increasing

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Yes, it has been put through -- it has been put through. During this scene, Flaemmchen has risen, piled up her glanced at her watch. During this action Flaemmchen to Zinnowitz that she is going down to dance, etc., is unaware of this action. Flaemmchen leaves the room not to attract attention.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: (to Preysing) What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: What's bluff?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (throwing the telegram on the table) That.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading at out loud) "Deal with Manchester definitely off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have thought it of you.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: No one would have thought it of me. I've been getting rusty in Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what the world wants I guess I can put up as big a bluff as anyone. From now on... (he turns away)

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: You must go to Manchester at once yourself and really see it through.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was desperate -- Now I don't care -- This sort of thing goes to a man's head.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: What you need is some relaxation.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd like to tear loose -- I'd like a drink. I'd like to go down to that dancing place. I'd like to start something.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: I can understand that -- after your -- uh --

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's the first time in thirty years that I've ever... Where's that stenographer? Miss Flaemm...

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: What do you want with her?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I want to see her, I want to do some dictating -- report of the conference  for my father-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: She had an engagement in the Yellow Room at five o'clock -- she was ina hurry.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Zinnowitz, would you say she was pretty?

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Pretty as a picture.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Let's go down and find her -- I need a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz. (he is picking up papers) I don't know anything about women -- been married for twenty-six years.

dialogues.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
dialogues.text: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does it. Goodnight. Preysing is very excited, they start to leave -- at that moment the telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Aeh! He crosses to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Hello... Father-in-law?... Is that you?... The agreement is signed -- I did it... yes, father-in-law... but now I must go to Manchester. When he picks the telephone up his hands are shaking --

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL SHAKER
dialogues.text: -- which shakes more. Music crashes up --

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE INTO BAR
dialogues.text: Kringelein and the Doctor are just entering. Kringelein is changed. His hair has been cut short and his moustache is gone, he looks almost saucy.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (to barman) Barman -- whiskey -- (to Kringelein) For you, Mr. Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: For me? -- Oh, please, something sweet and cold.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: A Louisiana flip, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: A Louisiana flip, that sounds very nice -- sweet, eh? -- During the following speech Kringelein keeps reaching for the moustache that is not there. He is thoroughly happy.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What do you do in the Grand Hotel? Eat -- sleep -- loaf around -- do business -- flirt a little -- dance a little. A hundred doors to one hall and nobody knows anything about the person next to him. When you leave another takes your room and lies in your bed -- the end. At that moment Flaemmchen enters.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Kringelein -- Where's the Baron?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for him here. The Baron and I have been together all day. A  carried hundred miles an hour -- in a motor car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was marvelous --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Kringelein -- How you have changed, you look so nice.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh, please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me, Miss Flaemm, won't you have something sweet -- a Louisiana flip. (to barman) A Louisiana flip.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (to barman) No - absinthe.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (amazed) Yes -- that -- Kringelein is beating time to the music -- a little away. Flaemmchen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You like music?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man might --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (mischievously) A man might what?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I'd like to do anything --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Oh -- you would! The Baron enters quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) Hello -- sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh -- here you are, Baron. A drink -- A Louisiana flip?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Kringelein. How do you feel now?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: A little strange, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: I'd given you up.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: A drink, Baron -- A Louisiana flip?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: No thanks -- keeping my head clear.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Dance then? (they exit)

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (to Doctor) She's beautiful -- isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (to Kringelein) Oh -- there are plenty of women.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: What have you been doing all day?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Chasing around.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Chasing what?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Money.  They dance a few steps, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You were very different yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Yesterday -- yes -- that was yesterday. They dance into the crowd. cur

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting what you're looking for?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: What, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: A masculine paradise -- drink, the ladies, dancing...

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I had a very good opportunity, a young lady asked me to dance -- I ought to be able to dance, it seems to be very important.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You must learn as quickly as your time allows -- Believe me Mr. Kringelein, a man who isn't with a woman is a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you all alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'm always alone -- I have been everything.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I was sent as a military surgeon to South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken prisoner. Home on parole not to fight. I was a surgeon in the Great War till the end. Grenade in the face. Carried diphtheria bacilli in the wound until 1920. Isolated two years. (pause) I've been everything. has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: That was lovely.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Will you do me a big favor?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: I'll do anything for you.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Would you like to make a man happy?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes -- I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Then dance the next number with Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You're not a bit like you were yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I fell in love last night -- the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- there's no real thing -- it doesn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I thought that, too -- but I found that it does. Come along, dance with Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Anything for you. They move off. As they approach the bar, happily Preysing pushes into scene, touches Flaemmchen's arm.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (with the Baron) Presently, Mr. Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Pardon me, the lady has urgent business here with me.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (to himself) Insolent -- Berlin manners. At that moment Kringelein has descended from the stool and crosses to Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I wish you a very good evening, Mr. Preysing. You are staying here, too, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- you must know me -- Kringelein at the plant. Assistant bookkeeper, building C, room twenty-three -- third floor.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Come and dance with me, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm -- business.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (lightly) Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: No -- now.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Do you gentlemen know each other, Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing -- Baron von Gaigern. They bow stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend and not accept your invitation to dance.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I could not think of not accepting.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You say that you are employed by us in Fredersdorf, and here you are in Berlin, indulging in diversions which ill befit your position and which are very much beyond your means -- Quite extraordinary, Mr. Kringelein, I think we will look into your books. Kringelein stands watching Preysing, his eyes narrowing.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Now, children, no fighting -- save  that for the office. Let's have our dance. (her arms go around Kringelein. They dance off)

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Oh, let the poor devil alone.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I did not ask your advice. The two men eye each other; for a moment there might be fight.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I think it would be much better if you went away.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: We shall see who remains here the longer.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (shrugging his shoulders) As you will. Preysing leans against the bar, orders a cognac. The Baron turns his back to him, watching the dancing.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You must look at my face and not at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You're trembling.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Kringelein's Flaemmchen's I never danced before -- in public.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You dance splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: For the first time in my life, I'm happy. Kringelein shows signs of exhaustion. Flaemmchen watches him quickly.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Let's stop -- I'm tired. It is obvious that she has stopped because of distress. They move arm.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Flaemm. back to the bar. Preysing catches

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You may go, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Does the world belong to you, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: What is this insolence?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Do you think you have free license to be insulting? Believe me you have  floor. not. You think you're superior, but you're quite an ordinary man.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Go away -- go away.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Please -- please!

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: You don't like to see me enjoying myself.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Who are you? -- An embezzler most likely.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: An embezzler -- you're going to take that back, right here in the presence of this young lady -- who do you think you're talking to? You think I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You're discharged.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get out -- you're discharged. Kringelein's hat has fallen from the stool upon the Flaemmchen picks it up, brushes it. Kringelein starts to laugh. The Baron steps into the scene. The Doctor slowly comes from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: You can't discharge me -- I'm my own master now -- at last. I'm ill, I'm going to die -- do you understand? I'm going to die very soon. Nothing can happen to me now. Nobody can do  the The Baron anything any more to me. By the time you can have discharged me I shall have been dead already. (his laugh becomes a convulsive sob) steps between the two looking straight into Preysing's face.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Come, Mr. Kringelein. (he pulls him out of the scene towards the bar)

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (his fists clenched, between his teeth) The man's insane -- he acts as if he is glad he is going to die... (hesitates -- to Flaemmchen) I shall see you in the lobby in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY OVER SENF'S HEAD
dialogues.text: General activity. The house chauffeur. detective, later identified, is talking to He leaves the chauffeur and crosses to Senf.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Better let him stay -- I've sent for the Baron... How's your wife coming along?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: I was at the hospital all night walking up and down the corridor. They wouldn't let me in to see her. She has the pains, but the child doesn't come and I have to stay here chained to this desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: I hope so. At that moment Preysing enters.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Did you send that page?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: The young lady's there, sir. Preysing glances off to see Flaemmchen standing looking around. Preysing crosses to Flaemmchen.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Sit here. (calls to a boy) Cognac -- for you?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Nothing. At that moment the Baron and Kringelein pass. Preysing glances up at Kringelein as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'm going to keep an eye on that Kringelein fellow. I'll find out where he gets the money to hang around the Grand Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Well -- you want me?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (looks straight at her) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I must go to England -- at once.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You see, I'd like to take a secretary with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody -- I don't know if you quite understand me. You said you have travelled with gentlemen -- and I mean --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: I understand perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: What do you think your salary would be -- for such a trip?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Wait -- I must figure it up. (she smokes and thinks) First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes -- it's cold in England in March, I'll need a suit... You'd want me to look nice?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Of course -- of course. (he is fidgeting)

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: A thousand marks -- (she waits anxiously thinking it might be too much)

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: It's agreed -- I will get a room here for you. She is looking away.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I can get a room here in the Grand Hotel for you. She still looks away.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Can you pay some attention to me?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (looking off) Insolent young cub!

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You mean Baron von Gaigern?

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Baron!

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Well, he's a gentleman! Who is leaning against a chair by a pillar with THE CAMERA APPROACHES THEM. They are not speaking. The Baron is looking off at:

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Sauntering between the door and Senf's desk.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: He slumps on the arm of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (watching him) The Baron is tired?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just -- (he shrugs his shoulders) Well -- well --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could go to the Casino -- the place we passed with the marvelous bright

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: commencing Baron

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: lights?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't -- I am broke!

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron -- The Baron looks off, sees the chauffeur --

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Arguing with Senf. cur

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein. (he strides off) Keep the CAMERA on Kringelein as he watches the Baron. He takes out his pocket-book and looks at his money to count it. The thought is in his mind of offering the money. Charming scene.

dialogues.speaker: BARON AND CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Moving into position. They are talking.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (quietly) I've quit.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'm not going to get those pearls and neither are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the money?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I'll pay you back.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I have an idea working in my head... (he glances at Kringelein)

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: You might find a bullet through that head...

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: If you did that, you'd get nothing except the police after you. If you wait -- I'll give you your six thousand back -- At that moment a voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car -- Madam Grusinskaya's car. It is passed along.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE PORTER
dialogues.text: (calls through his little telephone) Madam Grusinskaya's car --

dialogues.speaker: MEGAPHONE
dialogues.text: (outside) Madam Grusinskaya's car --

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (quickly to chauffeur) Later. (Chauffeur exits with bad grace.) Baron looks off...

dialogues.speaker: FROM HIS ANGLE
dialogues.text: shot. Meierheim. quickly Like a pageant Music comes up. Grusinskaya is People turn to As she gets to aside to him. Grusinskaya sweeps forward -- pretty followed by Suzette, Pimenov and look at her. She sweeps forward. the door she faces the Baron. She steps Pimenov and Meierheim pause.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (to them) Go on please -- go on, Suzette. She and the Baron are alone.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (quietly) Bless you...

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh -- I shall dance tonight -- How I shall dance -- I want to feel that you are in the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: No! I can't explain now. Oh, look -- the pearls. You wear them now...

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Why do you think --

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: They've brought me such good luck -- you -- He takes her hand, kisses it quietly.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: I'm worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: On the train?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Yes -- I will be on the train.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Till then.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Bless you -- During this scene Kringelein has been hovering nearby. Grusinskaya turns away and exits, Kringelein approaches Baron, who is standing perfectly still, looking off, -- mind miles away. The Baron

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Was the Baron joking, or is it really true that the Baron is -- in financial straits.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (lightly) Absolutely true, Kringelein and I have to raise some money immediately.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: If the Baron -- if you would permit me - looks at him suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I would be awfully glad to oblige, you've been so decent to me. Three hundred?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: If I could get into a game I might win some.  something door. back to

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Gambling! I'd like that. I have over six thousand eight hundred marks with me.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: If we could scare up some men to play.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: We could come to my room.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (with enthusiasm) Good! At that moment Flaemmchen passes.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Going?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Yes -- Flaemmchen hesitates as though she wanted to say that is on her mind. A curious little scene. She doesn't speak, she just turns suddenly through the The Baron glances after her a little puzzled, turns Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Ready, Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Ready, Baron. They move off and are last in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Possibly ten men are gathered about a green table. They playing cards. There are champagne bottles, glasses, on the table -- a great deal of smoke. Good atmosphere. game is [...] fer. There is a dead silence except for monotonous words of the players. White faced, the Baron has the bank. Otternschlag is seen to close the door quietly and the table. Kringelein's back is to us. They are smart people, not professional gamblers. There is a tension in the room. The men are gathered tightly. We do not see the cards. The following voices are heard:

dialogues.speaker: BARON'S VOICE
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: I play -- I play -- Here -- Up -- Playing --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes -- me. Several men glance at Kringelein and the size of his

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Is that too much, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (glances down at his  cards. learning a table to own money) No -- not at all.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: All right then.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: All right then. There is tension in the room. The Baron deals two Kringelein takes cards.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Don't show them. Kringelein turns it down. He is like a little boy new game. The Baron deals himself a card.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (to Baron) What do I do now? The Baron is serious. There is enough money on the take him to Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (next to Kringelein) Turn em up.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- that's right -- look! I win, don't I -- (he turns the card up) The Baron rises.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: There you are gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (to Kringelein) Will you take the bank, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes -- I'll take everything gentlemen -- please, let us drink -- champagne ---  champagne is expensive and good. I'm winning more than I used to earn in a year -- double what I used to earn. (he is counting his money) They hand him the cards. Kringelein kisses the Baron -- he looks around.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Where is the Baron -- where are you, Baron? At the side table the Baron is standing -- he is drinking -- his face is white -- he has lost.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (rising quickly) Excuse me, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (sitting down in Kringelein's place) I'll take the bank -- All right, gentlemen. Kringelein has come to the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: That was my last.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: You've lost everything?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I've no luck.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again... (he puts bills in Baron's hand.) Baron pours out a glass of champagne -- he has been drinking plenty -- he hands glass to Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my last chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I do drink, Baron -- I drink to you, Baron and to win. (he drinks) It's good, -- come along, Baron. They both move back to the table where the Doctor holds the bank.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I take five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: All of that at once, Baron? The Baron picks cards, shows them to Kringelein who doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Eight. (he is triumphant.)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (rings in background) Nine. The Baron throws the cards into the middle of the table and turns to Kringelein:

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: That's it. The luck's with you. (he walks away.)

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Come along, Mr. Kringelein. Sit here.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I'm having luck for the first time in my life.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: Your bank, Mr. Kringelein. Kringelein seats himself, puts his glass of champagne down on the table.  another Kringelein's has back Doctor leaves table, crosses to Baron who is pouring

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Out, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (bitterly) For a while -- I'll recover -- in ten or twenty years. (he points) Look at that. He has pointed and turned off because we hear

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I've won again, Baron -- I've won again. Baron moves out of scene followed by Doctor. As Baron approaches table.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Baron, I drink and win -- I drink and win -- I win and drink! (he is pulling money towards him, counting it, eagerly, frantically, not the movement of a miser, not a greedy movement, but the movement of an excited child liberated. Money has become so much mad paper to him.) During the foregoing scene, one of the men at the table answered the ringing of the telephone bell, he comes

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: There are complaints in the hotel about the noise.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: What time is it? Getting late? Let's  been up this no a Kringelein has break it up! (to Kringelein) You've been very lucky... Where's my coat? Let's go. He's drunk anyway!... Goodnight, Baron. Let's wind up the game, I'm broke and tired; you can't play against him. I put my hat down here, somewhere. I think I'll have a drink before I go. By the way, I've got to see you tomorrow morning. How've you been, Doctor? Business ad lib. General business of slow normal exit. Kringelein looks up from counting his money. He has like a little boy with a Christmas stocking. He looks suddenly, sees men are leaving --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, don't go, gentlemen! -- Stay a while. (he stands to his feet) Be my guests! By this time the men are pausing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I oughtn't to presume, but I -- (he is a little drunk) I'm so grateful to you -- it's been so marvelous. The first time in my life I have gambled -- I've danced! Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but it's the first time in my life I've ever tasted life!

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (slapping him on back) Splendid! There is a general feeling in the room that although man is drunk he is terribly sincere, and that there is wish to embarrass themselves or him. In fact, there is nervous impatient movement among the men. But reached an emotional pitch.  serious. him men

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but very dangerous. You must have courage for it, then it's wonderful. You gentlemen don't know that because you are all healthy and happy, but I -- believe me -- a man must know death and not until then does a man know anything about life.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (sings) Rejoice in life while yet the small lamp burns. General noise among men, some are ribald, others are Two men come and shake hands with Kringelein, bidding goodnight. The Baron puts his hand restrainingly on Kringelein's shoulder. Kringelein almost staggers towards the sideboard. The are nearing the door.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (starts singing) It's a short life and a gay one...

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (seizing a glass of champagne) Every glass high to life -- the splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to live it. (turns to Baron) Baron, you know -- I've only lived since last night -- but that little while seems longer than all the time before -- all the -- (he collapses suddenly onto the floor) Business ad lib. The doctor is there quickly. The Baron next.  Drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MAN
dialogues.text: Poor fellow. General normal business ad lib between the men. Perhaps three of them help him up, including the Baron. They carry Kringelein to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (of players mingling) Drunk? No, he's ill. Looks ill. (well paused over:) He's a doctor -- The doctor's here -- He's just drunk!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this man is ill -- very ill -- if you will leave.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Certainly, Doctor. Goodnight! Goodnight, Baron! Bad luck!

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MAN
dialogues.text: He's not used to champagne -- why does he drink it? Little comedy on exit. Ad lib. INTERCUT FOR RELIEF -- Kringelein's face -- white, drawn, tragic. One man, perhaps, remains.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Can I help, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No, the Baron will stay.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Certainly. Man leaves. During this scene the Baron has been carefully making Kringelein comfortable on the bed, bolstering pillows  course we see in his behind his head. Kringelein's eyes are shut tightly hands are limp. By the business of the Baron, although we do not of know it, this is the time that he takes the wallet from Kringelein and puts it in his own pocket. We might perhaps remember a sudden turn away in which his back and his right hand raised as though reaching inside pocket -- He stands looking down at Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (drops Kringelein's hand) It will be over in a minute. Kringelein's eyes flutter. His voice sounds hoarsely:

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Over -- over so soon -- it has just begun. (he closes his eyes suddenly) Oh, the pain.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Try and sleep, Kringelein, don't be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (mutteringly) I'd like to live a little longer but -- I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (touching his shoulder gently) You'll be all right, Kringelein. (he moves from the bed -- takes out a cigarette, moves to the table. He seizes his drink)

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (out of scene)  My pocketbook... my money in it...

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What do you say -- what? We watch Baron's face, he looks back over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You what -- Oh, isn't it there?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No -- But no I -- Baron, I've lost my pocketbook. Baron turns in this scene. He walks forward toward them. The Doctor's hands are on Kringelein's coat.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: There is no pocketbook here... On the floor probably. (He glances down)

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (starting up suddenly) More than fourteen thousand marks... were in that pocketbook.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (looking at Baron) Fourteen thousand marks... One can travel -- one's happiness might depend on fourteen thousand marks -- don't you think so, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (with a shrug) Quite possibly. At that moment, Kringelein, who has been staring up at the ceiling, his hands clenching and reclenching, starts up.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got to find it.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Stay where you are.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: the drunkenness, gets fascinated. No -- I must find it -- (he starts talking) Fourteen thousand two hundred marks. (he pulls himself to the side of the bed) The doctor goes to restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: I'm all right, Doctor. There's no pain now -- only you don't know what that money means to a man like me. He is suddenly on his hands and knees, crawling along floor, looking for it, like a little boy; his his condition, makes the situation tragic. He actually under the card table. The Doctor looks at the Baron. The Baron only watches Kringelein. He follows him,

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (talking at intervals as he crawls looking for money) You don't know, because you've never lived like a dog -- in a hole -- and saved and scrimped. My life hangs upon that money, Baron. Nobody gives you anything. You have to buy everything and pay cash for it. I wanted to pay for my last days with that money. Every hour costs money. I've nothing -- nothing but that pocketbook. (he crawls along the floor on his hands and knees talking to the carpet as he looks) I must have it back. (he pauses breathless -- like an animal along the wall -- looking up at the men)  action it bites isa stopped pity the but little looking and his The foregoing speech is intercut with the following in which Kringelein's voice is heard throughout -- thus is not a long speech: The Baron watches. He throws his cigarette away -- he his lip -- sweat breaks out upon his forehead; again he thief. When he wanted pearls the love of a woman him. Now he wants this money and pity, a slow growing for this tragic, dying thing is stopping him -- and all time the Doctor watches. The one, whole eye pierces into the Baron's melting conscience. Twice during the speech at a spot, through and during rehearsal, to be selected, the Doctor's voice, droning piercing, says:

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He must find his money, Baron. (next time) Mr. Kringelein should find his pocketbook, Baron, shouldn't he? These are two interjections. And now, Kringelein lies upon the floor, a troubled sack of pain, his head down. The Baron turns away. He bends down as though he were for the pocketbook. We see him take it from his pocket turn. There is a very light, almost triumphant ring in voice as he says:

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Here -- here it is. Here's your pocketbook, Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (his head coming up)  Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found it -- you found it for me, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: (quickly) Goodnight, Kringelein. (he moves towards the door.)

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: No -- no please -- oh, don't go -- don't go -- don't leave me alone, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Come, get up -- come let me help you. NOTE: If he is a strong actor he can pick Kringelein up If not, he and Doctor lift Kringelein to bed.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: You're all right now -- it's very late -- goodnight, Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay. Baron bites his lip. It is the first and only time in the play that we see a tear near -- the strong man almost breaks.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Goodnight. (his hand presses on Kringelein's shoulder -- he exits)

dialogues.text: Baron shuts door and pauses. In front of him is the the woman he loves. Down beyond is his own empty room. his pockets nothing. In his CLOSEUP he makes the feel his problem with him. This man who has lived and whistled and love through play becomes a tragic, lonely, harrassed figure. The has broken. His fists dig into his eyes -- he brushes hair back. Over this comes with almost an impertinence, a tiny He looks up and away down the corridor. The figure of Flaemmchen stands there, a small black bag in her hand. Baron pulls himself together and smiles characteristically. He walks down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen, what are you doing here in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: You live here?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: For tonight. (she points to door -- she looks at hima long time)

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Yes -- oh!

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.  of about tragically lamp adjoining puts his

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: And Baron, thanks so much for everything. They both go into their respective rooms. Here are our two gay young characters. The gay, fresh Flaemmchen and the debonair Baron, crucified for lack funds. Both trying to smile, both trying to be light themselves. Yet, each about to involve themselves for the want of a little money.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen enters her room cautiously. Except for one burning the room is in darkness and empty. From the door to Preysing's room a thin stream of light. She down her bag quickly, tiptoes through the bathroom to door. She peeps through.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: from her angle. Preysing stretched on bed flat, his stomach a mountain on it the magazine that he has been reading with picture. He is looking at the ceiling. She knows he is because a thin stream of smoke comes from his cigar in hand.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: An idea occurs to her. She could possibly sneak into he would go to sleep and there would be nothing that  closes hat and dress, starts of the room he speaks hair. deliberately CAMERA FOLLOWS HER as she tiptoes to her room. She the door noiselessly and listens. She throws off her takes off her coat. Opens her bag and takes out night lingerie, etc. The lid of her bag falls suddenly. She at the noise. "Has it awakened him." She looks off.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT AT BATHROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: The thin stream of light is filled suddenly, the door adjoining room opens and back-lighted from the other the huge form of Preysing appears. In this odd lighting is a little more than Preysing. He comes forward. He hoarsely, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen! (he seizes her to him) She goes to his arms passively. He rubs his face in her She is passive -- cold.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) You are late. I've been waiting for you -- waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: I had to arrange about the trip.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You're sweet.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You think so? He holds her again, trying to kiss her. She avoids his kiss.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Come here. (he sits heavily on  under the bed, sitting on her night dress.)

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Here, hold up! Preysing rises while she pulls her night dress from him. He draws her to him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (pulling away, glad of an excuse for conversation) Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said: 'How do you do, Mr. Preysing! And you said: (she imitates him) That was the young lady who was my secretary in Manchester Preysing laughs. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: That's all quite proper.  onto the sees a puzzled. moves French furtively collar wallet. forward, other. (she is happy again. She would rather talk than be squeezed) But supposing I met you when you were with your wife and I called out: "Hello you big baby -- remember Manchester?' And you with your wife, how would you like that? There is a pause for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my wife out of this. Flaemmchen yawns straight in his face.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: All right. I'll get undressed -- get out. He moves towards the windows which are open. She pushes fat body out, almost playfully, through the doors and the balcony. Preysing stands out on the balcony. He looks down in street below, then off. He starts suddenly because he shadow over the railing of his own balcony. He is Shadow crosses again. "Who can be in his room?" He forward and peeps through the window. One side of the window is closed. From his angle we see the Baron searching the room. He is now wearing an overcoat, the is turned up. Business ad lib. He finds Preysing's He stuffs this in his overcoat pocket. Preysing's face watching him. As Baron turns to exit, Preysing surges pulling the window after him. The two men face each

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?  room, grasps at telephone, and The Baron

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: I must have made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We shall soon see if you made a mistake. (the Baron starts to leave.) (bellowing) Stay here... Give me that money. hands him the pocketbook without a word.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: So that's how we stand, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's a matter of life or death -- I had to get some money -- tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must. Humm -- humm, but you must go to jail, Baron, you're a thief.

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'm going to call the police. I'm going to watch you play the great Baron with the police. Aristocrat! Aristocrat! (he picks up the telephone) The Baron makes for the door on the other side of the pulls at the knob.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: The door is locked, Baron. The Baron makes one dive across the room. Preysing his coat and tears it. With one hand holding the (the receiver dropping on its cord towards the ground  one hand holding the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Hello! Hello! --

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Don't do that. (he tries to snatch the telephone from Preysing.) Preysing wrenches the telephone suddenly away from the Baron. The action excites him.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: Strike me, would you? Attack me would you? Attack me -- With a terrific lunge, Preysing brings the telephone down upon the Baron's head. The Baron sways, stunned. (as in book). In his mad rage, Preysing, hits again with the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- Strike me! By this time the Baron is a heap on the floor. We see Preysing come out of his blind trance. He even repeats again.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: I strike you -- (with telephone foolishly in his hand, he looks down at what he has done.)

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS TELEPHONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Sharp sound of buzzing. Dozing night girl plugs in, lazily.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT GIRL
dialogues.text: so:
