dialogues.speaker: PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: New angle. Preysing is on his feet. He has replaced the receiver on the telephone, he is putting it back is terrified. Door opens behind him. Flaemmchen, with a dressing gown on, light, filmy crosses and looks down at the Baron, without a word. seizes her. Her hand goes to her head, her eyes roll; for a moment think she is going to faint right on top of the Baron. is trying to collect her senses, it cannot be true. We hear nothing but the heavy breathing of Preysing and traffic below. Suddenly a motor horn in the street below sounds it is the first time we have been conscious of it. With a swift movement, Flaemmchen dashes towards the It is locked. She rushes back as if to cut through her room. He reaches for her and rips her dressing gown her, leaving her almost naked. He lunges after her. She through her own room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that. running a "What is to looks She uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: windows. Doctor trousers clothes up.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen enters from her room. She looks this way and After all, it is Flaemmchen and not Lillian Gish, across the ice in "Way Down East," -- it is Flaemmchen, Berlin girl. She pauses to try and clear her brain. the hell is this -- what is it." The impulse naturally scream in alarm. She doesn't -- Flaemmchen's don't. She around. At the end of the passage is Kringelein's room. will go there. We watch her run down the passage Without knocking she pushes open Kringelein's door.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: It is in darkness. The only light comes through the The form of Kringelein lies prone upon the bed, the had just thrown a coat over him. He is still in his and shirt. Like a ghost, Flaemmchen, the shreds of her filmy hanging to her, crosses.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (hoarse whisper) Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein -- where are you? She sweeps to bed. She shakes him. Kringelein starts

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: their must assumes a pauses he Oh -- what -- what -- (he is looking up at what seems to be a ghost.) She pulls on the light by the bed, it flames up on faces.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Quick -- something awful -- awful has happened. Go -- go at once, -- Mr. Preysing --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Preysing? It occurs to him that this girl with her torn clothes have been roughly treated by Preysing. He suddenly strength.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful -- it's awful. She slides down to the floor, by the side of the bed. Kringelein climbs out of bed, tries to help her up.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Stay here. She waves him away.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing. Kringelein assumes suddenly a strength. He is a man for crisis -- he forgets that he was ever ill -- he leaves. WE GO WITH HIM. CUT HIM DOWN CORRIDOR QUICKLY. He outside Preysing's door, uncertain of the rooms, then knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: quickly

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: is pounds lying -- come hand.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (calling) Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing -- He feels there must be a mistake -- he steps back, sees Flaemmchen's door open next to it. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: He enters. Looks around. Looks through bathroom. Goes forward.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Preysing is still leaning against the table, his mouth open, he is gaping -- stunned. The two hundred and four has collapsed and sagged. He is staring, his victim a heap upon the floor, very still and quiet. His eyes around as Kringelein enters. Kringelein crosses, looks down. Touches the Baron's

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: -- We must do something...

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Yes, the police must be called.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a burglar -- he was going to steal my money.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Where is that girl -- she was working with him -- she enticed me into her room.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: (frantically) I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this -- but that girl -- the scandal -- my wife -- my daughters, you know them?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I know them --

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: The scandal -- we are men -- you -- you could take that affair of the young lady upon yourself -- take her and hold your tongue. Then you can travel -- I'll give you anything -- anything -- she was with you.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: We must call the police, your excellency. Preysing takes him by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: How much -- how much do you want -- you need money -- you have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me, Mr. General Director Pryesing -- worry about yourself. (he picks up receiver) There has been a murder -- this is

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: man.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: turns on the

dialogues.text: Telephone room one sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: girl plugs in.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Hello -- hurry up... hurry up... someone in one sixty-four says there has been a murder.

dialogues.speaker: HALL PORTER
dialogues.text: The scene gradually grows intense. Porter calls night

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Here - quick - here -- go to one sixty-four immediately. (calls back on telephone) Give me Mr. Rohna -- Rohna the manager.

dialogues.speaker: ROHNA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Darkened room. Bell ringing. Rohna sits up in bed, light, picks up telephone; on his face we see him hear news.

dialogues.speaker: ROHNA
dialogues.text: Where?... murder?... who?... all right, I'm coming. Wait a minute. (speaks in a monotone) Instruct everyone to use the utmost tact -- we must have no scandal in the Grand Hotel. Answer no questions, I'm coming now -- inform the police. (he replaces the telephone commences dressing quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ina the

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Trunks standing around everywhere. Suzette is finishing packing. Grusinskaya is sitting in front of the mirror loose night wrap -- she is doing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam should sleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (rising) In the middle of the night -- those flowers make me think of a funeral. Laurels and tube-roses. (she pushes the window closed, shivers, it is chilly. She crosses the room turning out one of the lights) Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Suzette. Suzette leaves -- turning out a light. Alone, Grusinskaya goes to the telephone. She raises receiver.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Hello -- can you tell me if Baron von Gaigern is in his room -- ring

dialogues.speaker: SLOWLY
dialogues.text: him. (talking to herself) Cherie, I must wake you or you'll miss the train. (into phone) ..yes... are you ringing, he may be asleep. (to herself) Cherie, you must get up and fetch me from my room -- I'm longing for you, Cherie -- I have not been to sleep -- I kept thinking you would come to me. (into phone) ..Oh, but he must answer. Ring -- ring -- ring. CUT IN HERE at discretion the:

dialogues.speaker: BARON'S EMPTY ROOM
dialogues.text: Telephone is ringing. cur

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Cherie, hurry -- hurry -- hurry. Answer the phone -- what is the matter. (into phone) Ring him -- ring him. (to herself) Where are you -- where are you, Cherie? Why don't you answer? (into phone) Well, ring him -- please -- please.

dialogues.text: General early morning bustle and activity. From one van, fruit and vegetables are being unloaded. another, huge hind quarters of beef are being carried in a monotonous way a baker throws two loaves at a another man, from a van backed up --

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: (counting) Forty-two -- forty-four -- forty-six -- forty-eight -- fifty -- fifty-two -- Waiters coming to work. A noisy racket. Sandwiched between the bread and butcher vans, is hearse. At the moment we come upon it, the men are pausing in work to glance. The men take off their caps, as; by the hotel detective and others, who will be there, corpse of the Baron in the basket, used at such time, brought out and placed in the hearse, which drives away. dialogues.speaker: BAKER

dialogues.text: Early morning. Sense of chill and desolation. Some stand on tables. A vacuum cleaner is at work on the Newspaper boys are delivering papers at the news stand. various shops are slowly being opened, the windows cleaned. The general feeling of the beginning of another day. THE CAMERA waits at a distance shooting from door as with a plain clothes man on either side of him, leaves towards THE CAMERA. He is grim, his hat is drawn over eyes. His hands deep in his pockets. When he has passed

dialogues.speaker: SENF'S DESK
dialogues.text: (the old shot) Meierheim is entering quickly goes the door. He crosses now to Pimenov. They talk eagerly out of But it is apparent that Meierheim is, as usual, ina  stand, telephone he is Rohna is there too. One of the men carries a telephone wrapped loosely in paper. But we know it's the stand. Senf comes on duty, looks around, it is apparent that late.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: And the child isn't coming?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Good heavens. What for?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Most imposters are -- A number of bellboys march up and form a line. Senf comes from behind the desk and inspects them.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Show your hands. They show their hands.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: (to one boy) You have dirty nails -- you little pig -- you're no good... Caps off! -- Let's see your hair. (Boys take off their caps) Good -- caps on! (Boys put on their caps) Where is number seven?... Not here? (to clerk) Take his name -- if he comes late again today, he's fired. Dismissed! The boys sit down on the bench. THE CAMERA MOVES TO KRINGELEIN. Kringelein and the police officer move towards the desk in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: speaking to has

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: looking hair, ear shot.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Please, officer.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: That will be sufficient for the present, sir, you may travel in peace. Kringelein exits.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR BY ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: As Kringelein emerges from the elevator, Suzette the Floor Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: And they've taken him away.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR CLERK
dialogues.text: Yes -- it's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam must not know -- you understand -- Madam must not know.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR CLERK
dialogues.text: I will tell the maids. I cannot answer for downstairs -- Suzette hurries down corridor. By this time Kringelein arrived at his door, he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Kringelein opens the door and enters. Flaemmchen is into space. A lovely picture. Morning light over her she is dressed.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron -- Lying there, his eyes so open.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: You loved the Baron, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: So did I. He was friendly to me as no man ever was.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps he really was a burglar -- But they don't kill a man for that.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: He was in desperate straits. He'd been trying to raise money all day. He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a man like Preysing kills him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (naively) I didn't like Preysing right off.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Then why did you have anything to do with him?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: (simply) Money!

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, -- money!

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You don't understand that do you?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Of course I do -- I never knew what money really meant till I started spending it. Do you know -- (he is silent a moment) I can hardly believe that anything so beautiful should come to me from Preysing -- I'll take care of you. Will -- will you let me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: You'll have a good time with me. Want to? I've got enough money. Ten thousand two hundred in my pocketbook. Three thousand four hundred that I won. It will last a long time. I can win more -- we'll travel.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there always.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Wherever you like. Here I'll give you the money I won, three thousand four hundred. Later you can have more.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Later?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It will not be long -- I'll not last long. Will you stay with me until...

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor, he'll cure you. They can cure anything these days.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Do you believe that you will have a better time with me than you would with Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Oh yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (takes her hands) Do you like me better?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein -- a very good man. Kringelein straightens, happy, inspired, a smile on his face.  He assumes in his gestures. Takes the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (into telephone) When is the next train leaving for Paris? -- Yes... Get two tickets for me... and my bill please... and the lady's -- Miss Flaemm's. (puts down telephone) (to Flaemmchen) We have to hurry let's pack -- we'll have breakfast on the train.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The figure of Grusinskaya is standing at her door, there is no one with her. Suzette steps out.

dialogues.speaker: SUZETTE
dialogues.text: Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is waiting downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov? (she looks off.)

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF PIMENOV
dialogues.text: coming out of the elevator. Grusinskaya hurries down to Pimenov -- they meet.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) He will be on the train.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: But when did he go? How do you know? She crosses and looks in the Baron's room. A maid is there changing the bedding. The room is unoccupied otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Baron von Gaigern has left? The maid nods.  like

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Suzette

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: When? How long ago? Maid shrugs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF FLOOR CLERK
dialogues.text: The Baron left about half an hour ago, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: Oh -- Gru -- come, come -- we'll lose the train. While they are waiting for the elevator Grusinskaya is a live electric wire. The elevator arrives. They are stepping in.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: General activity. We hear the cry go up:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car... Grusinskaya comes out of the elevator followed by and Pimenov. Meierheim meets her.

dialogues.speaker: MEIERHEIM
dialogues.text: Come along, oh, Madam, come along. The train will be going.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: What's the use of asking, Gru -- he is at the train -- He will be there.

dialogues.speaker: MEIERHEIM
dialogues.text: The troupe, the scenery, everything -- all on board, waiting. You have a rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning. Come, Madam, are you mad? Grusinskaya crosses to the desk. She speaks to Senf.  the

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: sunlight

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Have you seen Baron von Gaigern?

dialogues.speaker: ROHNA
dialogues.text: (comes over quickly) The Baron is not here, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: He is gone?

dialogues.speaker: ROHNA
dialogues.text: Yes, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MEIERHEIM
dialogues.text: Four minutes past. Please come.

dialogues.speaker: PIMENOV
dialogues.text: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there -- he will be there.

dialogues.speaker: MEIERHEIM
dialogues.text: (calling) Madam Grusinskaya's car. Grusinskaya, followed by the others, sweeps out towards door.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR HOTEL
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya emerges, followed by the others. The hits them.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in Tremezzo

dialogues.speaker: MEIERHEIM
dialogues.text: Every seat for the opening has been sold at Vienna. Sold out for three days.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
dialogues.text: I know -- I know -- but it will be sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest then.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: of still (knowingly) Yes, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car. Grusinskaya moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: (at telephone) Grand Hotel, Head Porter. What? There's been -- a child born? A boy! Yes! My child born! It is healthy... and my wife? Doing well -- all well! (to Clerk) The child has come. They are both alive. My child...

dialogues.speaker: BY ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: At this moment Kringelein and Flaemmchen are coming out the elevator, Kringelein is carrying his suitcase. A bellboy attempts to take his bag but Kringelein, confused draws his hand with the suitcase away from the bellboy.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Let him take it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: Your bag, your Excellency -- Hearing the word 'Excellency' Kringelein goes through a transformation. He stands and with a flourish hands the suitcase over to the boy. He is a big man now.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (very definitely to boy) Cab please!  move Boys triumphant door. leaves opening

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: Cab, for his Excellency, Mr. Kringelein!

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) And now we travel, Flaemmchen... Glad?

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: Am I!

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Is the bill ready -- the lady's too?

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: At once. Any forwarding address, Mr. Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Yes, Paris -- Grand Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: How do you know there is a Grand Hotel?

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN
dialogues.text: Oh, there must be one in Paris... They have everything in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: SENF
dialogues.text: Your bill, Your Excellency. Kringelein pays and taking Flaemmchen's arm starts to away from the desk, General business ad lib of tipping. line up, making a deep bow. There is almost a march as Kringelein and Flaemmchen move towards the

dialogues.speaker: SENF CLERK BOYS
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Come again, your Excellency. With head erect, happy smile on his face, Kringelein the lobby. Normal activity in lobby, reminding us of scene. Doctor comes up to desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that Mr. Kringelein leaving?
